module.p: bi be is the predicative simple verb.

section.p:
The principal parts of bi are –
tha / (bh)eil – present independent/dependent – is, are, am
bidh / bi – future independent/dependent – will be
bha / robh – past independent/dependent – was, were
bhiodh / biodh – conditional independent/dependent – would be
bith – verbal noun – being

ul.li:
present
active
independent – tha
relative – a tha
dependent – chan/nach eil, a bheil
passive
independent – thathar
relative – a thathar
dependent – chan/nach eilear, a bheilear

past
active
independent – bha
relative – a bha
dependent – cha/an/nach robh
passive
independent – bhathar
relative – a bhathar
dependent – cha/an/nach robhar

future
active
independent – bidh
relative – a bhios
dependent – cha bhi, am/nach bi
passive
independent – bithear
relative – a bhithear
dependent – cha bhithear, am/nach bithear

conditional
active
first person singular
independent – bhithinn
relative – a bhithinn
dependent – cha bhithinn, am/nach bithinn
first person plural
independent – bhiomaid
relative – a bhiomaid
dependent – cha bhiomaid, am/nach biomaid
second/third persons
independent – bhiodh
relative – a bhiodh
dependent – cha bhiodh, am/nach biodh
passive
independent – bhite
relative – a bhite
dependent – cha bhite, am/nach bite

independent
first person singular – bitheam!
second person singular – bi!
first person plural – biomaid!
second person plural – bithibh!
third person – bitheadh!
passive – rach(t)ar!

dependent
first person singular – na bitheam!
second person singular – na bi!
first person plural – na biomaid!
second person plural – na bithibh!
third person – na bitheadh!

Note the following emphatic variants –
bidh ⇒ bithidh
a bhios ⇒ a bhitheas
b[h]iodh ⇒ b[h]itheadh
b[h]iomaid ⇒ b[h]itheamaid

Note the following passive dialectal alternatives –
thathar ⇒ thatar, thathas
b[h]eilear ⇒ b[h]eileas
bhathar ⇒ bhatar, bhathas
robhar ⇒ robhas
b[h]ithear ⇒ b[h]itear, b[h]itheas, b[h]iteas
b[h]ite ⇒ b[h]iteadh

section.p:
bi is used in subject-predicate constructions –
Tha an cù dubh.
The dog is black. td. 6
Tha an cat aig an teine.
The cat is by the fire. td. 6
Tha Màiri ag obair.
Mary is working. td. 6
A bheil an cù aig an dorus?
Is the dog at the door? td. 11
Nach eil Calum anns an achadh?
Isn’t Malcolm in the field? td. 11
The subject of bi can be a noun or a pronoun.

Some examples –
proper nouns –
Tha Màiri sgìth.
Mary is tired. td. 7
Tha Calum ag obair.
Malcolm is working. td. 7
Tha Màiri bhàn anns an achadh an diugh agus tha i ag obair gu trang.
Fair-headed Mary is in the field today and she is working busily. td. 9
Nach eil Calum anns an achadh?
Isn’t Malcolm in the field? td. 11
common nouns –
animate –
Tha an cat bàn.
The cat is white. td. 6
Tha an cù dubh aig an dorus.
The black dog is at the door. td. 9
inanimate/abstract –
Tha an dorus mór.
The door is big. td. 6
Tha teas anns an teine.
There is heat in the fire. td. 6
Tha falt dubh air Calum ach tha falt bàn air Màiri.
Calum has black hair but Mary has fair hair. td. 9
personal pronouns –
Tha sinn trang.
We are busy. td. 7
Tha e fuar an diugh.
It is cold today. td. 7
Tha Màiri bhàn anns an achadh an diugh agus tha i ag obair gu trang.
Fair-headed Mary is in the field today and she is working busily. td. 9
A bheil thu sgìth?
Are you tired? td. 11
Chan eil e fuar an diugh.
It is not cold today. td. 11
examples with agus and –
Tha Màiri agus Calum ag obair.
Mary and Malcolm are working. td. 7

The predicate of bi can be an adjective or a (static) preposition –
Tha Calum sgìth.
Malcolm is tired. td. 7
Tha an cù aig an dorus.
The dog is at the door. td. 6
The predicate of bi can be an (uninflected) adjective.

Examples with different kinds of subject –
common nouns –
animate –
Tha an cù dubh ach tha an cat bàn.
The dog is black but the cat is white. td. 6
Tha an cù mòr ach tha an cat beag.
The dog is big but the cat is small. td. 6
inanimate –
Tha an dorus mór agus tha an teine mór.
The door is big and the fire is big. td. 6
proper nouns –
Tha Màiri beag ach tha Calum mór.
Mary is small but Malcolm is small. td. 6
Tha Màiri agus Calum trang an diugh.
Mary and Malcolm are busy today. td. 7
Tha Màiri bheag sgìth.
Little Mary is tired. td. 9
personal pronouns –
Tha sinn trang.
We are busy. td. 7
Tha iad fuar ag obair anns an achadh an diugh.
They are cold working in the field today. td. 7
Tha mi fuar agus tha mi sgìth.
I am cold and I am tired. td. 9
Tha iad fuar anns an achadh an diugh.
They are cold in the field today. td. 9
A bheil thu sgìth?
Are you tired? td. 11
non-referential, ‘dummy’ pronouns –
Tha e fuar an diugh.
It is cold today. td. 7
Chan eil e fuar an diugh.
It is not cold today. td. 11
The predicate of bi can be a (static) preposition.

Examples with different kinds of subject –
common nouns –
human –
Tha Màiri bhàn anns an achadh an diugh agus tha i ag obair gu trang.
Fair-headed Mary is in the field today and she is working busily. td. 9
Tha sibh aig an teine.
You are at the fire. td. 9 [226]
Nach eil Calum anns an achadh?
Isn’t Malcolm in the field? td. 11
other animate –
Tha an cù aig an dorus agus tha an cat aig an teine.
The dog is at the door and the cat is by the fire. td. 6
A bheil an cù aig an dorus?
Is the dog at the door? td. 11
inanimate/abstract –
Tha teas anns an teine.
There is heat in the fire. td. 6
Tha falt dubh air Calum ach tha falt bàn air Màiri.
Calum has black hair but Mary has fair hair. td. 9
More specifically, the predicate of bi can be the progressive particle ag, followed by a verbal noun.

Some examples –
Tha Màiri agus Calum ag obair anns an achadh an diugh.
Mary and Malcolm are working in the field today. td. 6–7
Tha Màiri bhàn anns an achadh an diugh agus tha i ag obair gu trang.
Fair-headed Mary is in the field today and she is working busily. td. 9

bi can take more than one predicate, without needing an explicit conjunction agus and –
Tha Màiri beag bàn.
Mary is small and fair-haired. td. 8
Tha iad fuar ag obair anns an achadh an diugh.
They are cold working in the field today. td. 7
Tha sinn trang ag obair.
We ae busy working. td. 9

But see also –
Tha Màiri agus Calum fliuch agus fuar.
Mary and Malcolm are wet and cold. td. 7 [226]
bi can occur with one or more modifiers.

Examples with temporal modifiers –
Tha iad fuar ag obair anns an achadh an diugh.
They are tired working in the field today. td. 7
Tha Màiri bhàn anns an achadh an diugh agus tha i ag obair gu trang.
Fair-headed Mary is in the field today and she is working busily. td. 9
Chan eil e fuar an diugh.
It is not cold today. td. 11

Examples with locative modifiers –
Tha iad fuar anns an achadh an diugh.
They are cold in the field today. td. 9
Tha sinn trang anns an achadh.
We are busy in the field. td. 9 [226]
